Pros: It's the place to learn e-commerce (platform) and the driving force behind it (user growth, seller growth, product assortment, dynamic pricing, fulfilment etc.). Regardless of which department or function you're attached to, the exposure to the business is almost direct. Great for learning. Love the mega campaign seasons. It's hectic, but everyone works towards a common goal.
Cons: The relentless pursuit for more growth (not unexpected) layered with unnecessary constraints from group/regional doesn't go hand-in-hand most of the time, or at all. Some constraints are okay. But some were outright ridiculous (i.e. no hiring due to lack of demonstrated growth). When commercial roles are bogged with administrative tasks that takes up 70-80% of their time. This is not a good use of their time/resource.

Summary: DO NOT COME HERE, FOR YOUR OWN GOOD

Summary: Lack of direction from the Snr management!
Pros: The company environment is conducive and it provide a place for everyone to feel homely and comfortable to work.
Cons:
1. Lack of clear direction from the management roadmap.
2. Preach and doing it is so different 
3. Now has Alibaba and Cainiao inside Lazada. Yet Lazadians didn't have much freedom to voice out issue and unhappiness.
4 Yet Cainiao is duplicating the business and working on lazada leads yet didn't contribute much to lazada only for Cainiao benefits
5. The hidden internal politics is confusing everyone on the ground. So are we working as lazada direction or only leading towards Cainiao directions?
6. Plus Cainiao directors to lead lazada business growth in lazada South East Asia Yet didn't provide a concrete road map to review better strategy for lazadians.
7. The HR is a problem here...lack of clear directive when looking for candidates...people come people go with such high turnover causing the VP and SVP so many issues on the ground. 
8. All founders have left the company and now only a few around waiting for cash payout...then what's the point of telling everyone that lazada will be listed? Yet vesting the shares out..everyone has yo pay high tax again?

Cons:
Comp and Benefits severely under market amongst Tech firms 
Diversity and inclusion - close to zero where its a predominantly Chinese led, Chinese culture. Senior Management are only starting to (after 4 years of acquisition) understand but yet to master the importance of localisation. 

Culture and values - Senior Management - next-to-zero experience in managing any portfolio outside of China, lack of respect for local cultures no work life balance. 996 does not work outside of China or anywhere else in the world, except, China. 

In Singapore, Commercial team is led by a Chief Commercial Officer with the emotional maturity of a teenager, supported by Senior HR who espouses building cultures but only has a decade of experience in a commodities firm. yes, growing agriculture and promoting culture from like the Industrial revolution and force fitting it into a 'dynamic, ecommerce, 24/7 firm'. Yes thats the reason why there's no growth, and a 1950s culture - read - slow, lethargic, indecisive, lack of innovation - in the commercial team which are supposed to be the most dynamic function of all verticals. Recently employing a Chief Marketing Officer from Singapore's Trade Union association. Want to have innovating marketing and branding? yes that's right, go the opposite direction and pick someone who's from the Unions to help a dynamic, young, trendy organisation!

And you have leadership like Commercial officer in Malaysia who has basically close to 50% attrition in her team and has been nothing but n excellent individual contributor but has risen to where she is because - yes you guessed it - Chinese.

Summary: Get what you need,  move on
Pros:
Plenty of skilled and knowledgeable colleagues in the eCommerce space 
Great work experience for young in career people 
If you can survive here, you will thrive anywhere!
Cons:
Chaos, some controlled, some created, but always a short-term crisis to deal with, and changes made on the fly. The excuse that 'its eCommerce, things move fast in this environment" is not always applicable. Sometimes it is poor planning and execution. 

High turnover. Lots of talent leaving, all the time. 

Senior management who are not competent, but protected by those above. Tough in a company that has a hard performance management system that denies a bonus to those identified as poor performers. Note the word identified. And no appeal process if you disagree.

Still lacks a real culture. A big issue. To be fair, they work on it, but throwing money at it isn't the answer. Deeper understanding is required.

Cons:
- Very very very political bosses (not leaders) whom only focus on finger pointing rather than solving or preventing the problem from occurring again.
- Decks and decks of sop which are not aligned among all department which results in lots of miscommunication.
- not all but there are several higher-ups which are clearly incompetent at all sitting comfortably in places giving out orders without direction, unable to solve problem or give solutions/ advices as well. But goes all raging when problems are actually solved independently or among the lower rank staffs for not "going through" them. Nonetheless, there are still some amazing leaders from other department who will always be willing to guide and help
- HR needs to be more transparent and proactive in listening to the feedbacks of the staffs, rather than turning a deaf ear or ignoring the problems thats happening in particular departments such as MS team. Despite having several red flags known/ flagged by all other department and past employees
- Overall is a good company, but having several red apples sitting in spots totally destroy the experience or growth prospect of employees particularly MS.

Summary: Very fast-paced personal growth, however be wary of poor management & team leadership
Pros:
- Great opportunities to work across different projects outside of your scope of work
- Great visibility with other team and management due to different projects that you can get involved in
- Flat organization where you can approach bosses above you for any idea/project; not big on organizational structure or ranking
- Very clear corporate culture and helpful teammates all around
Cons:
- Very long hours; which is expected in eCommerce
- You tend to do more workload than what is assigned to you, especially since the turnover rate is very high 
- Hiring is very slow for team; making your team overloaded with covering tasks while waiting for replacement
- Management team has no clear strategic direction on where the company is headed to; resulting in change of decision and you spending a lot of time fire-fighting in the organization
- Some teams (including mine) have toxic work culture; where the boss is more interested in office politics and delegating work in spite of the team being overloaded
- Lack of transparency in career growth and promotion; with subjective measurement being used to deny promotions
- Human Resource Department behaves in favour of the management, making it challenging for the staff to bring forward specific feedback for improvement

Summary: Life Below the Powerhouse as Local Software Engineer
Pros:
You have the flexibility to do exploration and build your own product as you may have the capability to access the stack to the tech giant even though sometimes it may be limited due to several constraint and especially the scale. You will have the right to analyze, offer, and implement your best solution here which sometimes the simplest solution can lead to big contribution to company and it's exciting.

If you're interested in something, there will be a proper private learning class which you can take and do self development which is super useful, as you can actually learn anything in there from engineering, product, even the non-engineering part is accessible there. 

Most of the time it will be like a startup level bootstrapping as you will have so many discussions and understand the business flow and background properly which makes you not only as an engineer, but also the business / product owner.

You have good allowance for transportation and phone bill which vary on each position / levels and also you have quite good work life balance (unless you will need to have a shift or overtime during events, you may get leave benefit though)
Cons:
At certain point, your skill level will not be a caliber of higher level engineer as the main technological stack is already in place from the parent company / regional and not accessible unless it's related to you. Most of the time you will be a lone wolf as the team is too lean or maybe lackluster which if you don't have the initiative and commitment to grow, you will just be another person that will be easily replaceable and a contributor to the high number of the turnover. There is no such thing as nurturing and pair programming / review, and other beautiful things as you hope in engineering. Do your own stuff, grow yourself, ask someone, find something on the documentation (even though most of them might not be readable, you can use google translate on the documentation page hoping that it's understandable). Some people are helpful, some might just want to do their own business. 

Everyone has their own pride, there will be a case that you build a redundant product instead of working together to achieve something causing the lost of resource of manpower and other imaginable bad things in this case. 

There will be some days that you won't be an engineer, but more like an operation based worker which needs to help low level issue but very long process need to be passed which usually some of the process are actually a pass through process which is quite useless. (if you want to grow as a real software engineer, go apply to regional in Vietnam instead of on local level venture)

Sometimes you will be dragged to some random meeting which has no point and clarity because on venture level and you will be facing so many operation or business minded people instead of tech based people which you might get lost on what you want to build due to some drives from the business. Meaning if you don't do something visible to operation based, you can be regarded as no contribution.

Meeting may happen / most likely to happen right after office hour because there might be too much job for the upper level management which impacting the lower level position from senior -> mid -> junior level might need to follow the higher ups.

It might just be a matter 
of time that the local tech team will be disbanded and absorbed somewhere else.

Summary: Vibrant working place, am in a good team
Pros: Guidance available, decent laptop, flexible work hour
Cons: Workload increase faster than headcount hiring

Pros: It is a mixed culture of Chinese culture in the product team. We have the chance to learn the latest e-commerce technology in the market trend.
Cons: Chinese language is an added advantages.

Pros:
- Opportunities to learn about e-commerce industry
- Internal rotation is not difficult. It is encouraged after 2 years
- Essentially a Chinese company - can be a pro or a con depending on what you are comfortable with
Cons:
- Most of the middle managers do not possess leadership qualities. No holistic performance review system (there is only top-down), which is odd because the company is not that young anymore. Some people managers are really toxic, but no one does anything about it because the upper management is ignoring this problem and likely unable to find solutions anyway... A lot of decent people managers have left the company. Some of the remaining people managers who are pretty decent try their best but the working environment and culture is just not supportive.
- Lack of direction. Lots of the work bring little or no impact to business. A lot of time is spent on meaningless manual work which does not really benefit anyone or the business. Other than the manual work, a significant part of people's time is spent by chasing or being chased over some Excel trackers. The company is still fixing issues that they should have done a few years back (you may now be wondering....what the company is spending time and money on...)
- Strong Chinese culture in the regional team (again, can be a pro or a con). Only a group of people from the parent company are empowered to make decisions, unfortunately these people do not have the time to make all the important decisions. Meanwhile, the middle managers are too afraid to make decisions because they cannot afford to lose their jobs if anything goes south.
- Lack of inclusion. Inability to communicate in Chinese is a huge barrier for progression in certain teams.
- "Change is the only constant" is one of the company values. Unfortunately, a lot of people misunderstand what it is supposed to mean. In reality, implementing too many and frequent changes results in inefficiencies and people leaving sooner than expected.

Pros: The environment and benefits are good
Cons: Some of the procedures are too complicated

Cons: eCommerce is like running a shopping mall online and you need to make sure sellers and buyers can get what they need, campaigns and customer care are a norm. Constantly pursuing higher targets could be taxing for some, but which company is easy to get and keep sales?

Summary: Join only if you know Chinese.
Pros:
- Impactful projects. 
- Fast paced = learn a lot.
- Free Udemy.
- Teammates are very nice and helpful.
- Flexible hours.
- High pay.
Cons:
- I was in technology and everything that was important was in Chinese. Documentation, dev tools, emails, group chats, etc. There's the google translate button but not everything can be translated.

- A lot of Chinese being used. Most of my group chats had the auto translation on, so it's fine but sometimes during video chats, they even breaks out into Chinese for a good while. You can imagine how it will make the non Chinese feel. And it feels like everything could have been done a lot faster if everyone just spoke Chinese.

- Managers are literally managers, don't expect leaders. They are just there to assign and probe you for your tasks. My voicing out of work concerns are met with deaf ears. Did not feel like I can approach manager for any troubles.

- Disgusting welfare efforts. There's almost no welfare. The most you'll get is an email (in Chinese) about how everyone is working hard and to keep it up. Absolute clownery. 

- Flexible hours also mean you could get pinged during your leave and routine OTs. Say bye bye to your WLB.

- Pay was high for fresher. But you forget about your pay when you're knee deep in stress and anxiety. Unless you're in dire financial needs, trust me, it's not worth it.

Summary: Company is drifting, no vision, no direction .....  so I left
Pros:
The people of Lazada remain the best thing about the company - smart, enthusiastic, hardworking and fun. 

The internal environment is free of politics. It is fast paced and the attitude is to get things done, quickly.
Cons: The leadership of Lazada is in shambles. The current group CEO - Chun Li - seems to be on not able to set the vision or provide a clear strategy. The company performance has been slipping over the past 12 months, losing share to competitors who are executing well. Chun doesn't seem to have any ideas nor the energy or charisma to lead the organization forward against this loss to competition. Attrition is very high, most people are leaving due to lack of direction and winning spirit. Lazada Indonesia (where Chun Li is also the CEO) is in a worse shape than rest of Lazada Group.

On-boarding process: HR welcome videos lacks of professionalism, provides pages of documents for reading but no interactive. security test is like " real test" heavily influenced by Alibaba culture i guess. if you want to have the flavour working in China 5-8 years ago, here is the deal.

senior management mostly is from Alibaba, does not have leadership quality such as good presentation skill, set strategy vision, English communication skills and leadership. they might be experts in e-commerce, but hardly you could see them to be employed in senior positions in any other companies. Overall talent quality varies.

My assigned HRBP asked to have 1 on 1 with me regarding my current statis right now with the company and she told me it will be kept confidential so I bursted out my issues and asks from the company. I've been in Lazada for almost 2 years and with the people I regularly work with, I'm used to placing my trust in them because they have proven so but this is a different experience. After expressing my opinions about salary, management direction, and some other personal stuff. I got a message from my manager asking me what's wrong with me and why didn't I told him first instead of telling the HRBP. 

Now in this case, I'm not upset at my manager's scolding and now being micro-managed. I'm upset with the fact that the HRBP I trusted snitched everything I told her even regarding it as "Confidential". In any case I just kept it for myself because it wont really do me good if I proceed with a direct confrontation.

Pros:
1. Fast pace
2. Smart people
3. Relatively fair salary
4. Join if you're young, has loads of stamina and has an aggressive attitude to reach hit KPI goals
Cons:
1. High pressure environment
2. Managers manage upwards, pressure downwards to achieve goals/KPI or overall performance will be evaluated poorly resulting in high turnaround from extreme stress and high burnout rate.
3. Fast pace resulting in short term planning and relatively low long term plans for longevity, as long as KPI is met, it's time to move on to the next thing.
4. Regionally managed by Alibaba managers, has little understanding of local country's culture and marketing relevancy, thus allowing the competitor to race ahead.
5. Very cliquey, you're either in (protected) or you're out (sink or swim)
6. The same smart people in 'pro' can end up being the bane of your existence so thread carefully.

Pros: They do not openly force you to come to work
Cons:
Singapore team

1. Highly relationship-driven, favours are given to people who curry favour superiors
2. Blame culture. when something goes wrong, instead of solving problems, people are more interested in pointing fingers 
3. Lack of innovation. New ideas are seldom executed because of fear of failure 
4. There is only one ultimate decision-maker. New ideas are seldom explored unless it comes from the ultimate decision-maker, then you are left to silently execute.
5. HR is a pretext to safeguard the management's interest, not for employees. Anything told in confidence will reach your manager. 
6. Complacent and reactive to competition 
7. Misaligned objectives between teams and departments. Mostly doing things to 'look good' on paper but do not think in the interest of the company 
8. People are promoted based on relationship while allowing good people to churn. 
9. No 360 feedback, no senior people would want to promote this
10. Culturally, newcomers are set-up to fail. People enjoy bringing you down to elevate their own esteem
11. Highly incompetent managers who have no basic business acumen and no leadership traits 
12. Lack of individuals who are truly passionate about the company
13. Even after several work complaints from different people, you will never be fired as long you gain yourself the status "friend of the office"
14. Very hierarchical and insecure managers 
15. People from other countries are more likely to render assistance than your own team members

Join only if you are beyond desperate. There is no glory in being part of Lazada SG. The competitions do not need to spare any effort in trying to win market share from Lazada. It will be Lazada's own undoing that it eventually fails. Something has to be done at the very highest to salvage whatever shred of honesty is left.

Summary: Read this before accepting an offer from Lazada Malaysia
Pros:
- Fun place to work at with the many activities and entertainments organised by the People Team throughout the many campaigns and occasions.

Reasons to accept an offer from Lazada Malaysia:
1. Lazada is pretty much a well-established brand in SEA. Will look good on your resume.
2. You are currently unemployed and really need the money.
3. You want to experience/learn about e-commerce industry.
Cons:
- If you are currently employed, stay there. Don't accept the offer from Lazada expecting it to be better.

Reasons NOT to accept an offer from Lazada Malaysia:

1. Top down communication is at its absolute worst, causing frequent changes in directions and instructions.

2. For an e-commerce giant that's turning 9 years old this year, the management of the organisation is still very much all over the place. Departments and processes have no properly established SOPs with the endless excuse that "this is a fast pace environment". Yes, "CHANGE IS THE ONLY CONSTANT" (one of Lazada's values), but it should also be expected. Hence, the need for SOPs.

3. People managing the teams are extremely lacking in people management skills. Managers only talk to you when they need something from you, so they can take credits for the things you do. Otherwise, you don't exist to them. Zero human touch. Credits are sometimes given, but in private.

4. If you accepted a position in Lazada Malaysia, be prepared to do works entirely out of the scope of your role/experience without any guidance or training for upskilling.

5. No matter how good you are at what you do, you will never be promoted or recognised if you don't su*k up to the management of your department. Doing your work excellently alone is not enough. You'll experience major career setback.

6. No one in the organisation can be trusted, not even the HR/People Team. If you have issues, keep it to yourself. Reporting to a higher level or the HR is just a waste of time. If you do, don't expect changes.

7. Your yearly KPIs will only be given to you 5-6 months into the new financial year. I got mine just 2 days before the deadline of mid-year review submission, and yes, I did ask for it earlier but the answer is always "waiting for management to review and approve".

8. For an industry that relies heavily on their customers (buyers and sellers), their Customer Care department is the LEAST liked department and often overlooked. The head of the department doesn't even put in the effort to elevate the Customer Care department. 

9. The activities organised by the People Team are fun, but very rarely inclusive. Most of the time, you will feel like an outsider looking in. The participants are mostly people from the so called Malaysia Management Team (MMT), HR, Category and Marketing teams.

10. Campaigns after campaigns after campaigns, it's a vicious cycle. Expect to work at least 12 hours on campaign days for absolutely no reasons. 

11. No matter the achievements on campaign days, don't expect big bonus and increment.

The list of cons is endless, but I think I've made my points. I'm only writing this for the sake of my friends who are still stuck there, because they are not able to secure another job yet during this pandemic. Praying they will get an out soon.

Pros: Good learning experience in e-commerce.
Cons:
Lazada is not meant for you if you want to make a positive impact on customer experience. You can also forget about building your career here unless you are Chinese, speak Mandarin, or enjoy being at the beck and call of everyone 24-7.

An unhealthy culture that glorifies long working hours, unproductive meetings, and doing whatever your boss tells you. Collaboration is not encouraged - competition is; breeding a toxic environment. People get promoted for their blinkered focus on KPIs that have no meaningful contribution to the business or the customer.

Many managers lack compassion/empathy and arenâ€™t capable of thinking laterally - the keys to success and career progression here. Your manager will only give you the time of day if they can claim credit for your work or if their neck is on the line - every man for himself!

HR only exists to discipline supposed transgressors and silence people who ask questions or give suggestions for improvement. If you decide to accept a role here, grit your teeth, put your head down, and stick it out for at least a year. Try not to stay too long because your career will stagnate, you will feel drained, and youâ€™ll likely lose your critical thinking skills.

Pros:
The scale at which Lazada operates is massive. Ecommerce at this scale does not happen at many places and being associated with Alibaba makes it a good brand to have on your resume.

It is also a good place to really learn how a massive e-commerce giant works, and multiple departments like commercial, marketing and logistics come together.
Cons:
While Lazada is a really big brand, toxic work culture has crept in over the years and there are unhappy people in almost every department now. People are highly stressed and there is no spirit of collaboration between teams. Employees are under immense pressure at all times, and hence do not want to build or do anything even slightly innovative around their core jobs. During my time, I saw at least two senior managers break down in tears due to stress. There is no work-life balance and the company simply goes from campaign to campaign without taking a break.

Promotions are offered as a way to retain people who threaten to quit. Saw several people get promoted out-of-cycle this way, resulting in an unnecessarily top heavy workforce. 

There is also no proper onboarding or training offered to new hires either. This is simply dismissed as "the Lazada way of doing things" (actual quote from an HR generalist), but burnout and attrition are super high, so there are always new people struggling to come up to speed. People would often be hired and find out on the day they joined that their role or scope had completely been changed since their interview. 

Finally, management changes and departures are very frequent making trust and faith in the company a real issue.

Summary: Great organisation with positive growth prospects
Pros:
- Team and Co-colleagues: Strongly knitted and cohesive team work.

- Clear Communications : Regular townhalls and briefing from C levels, HR and HODs.

- Excellent SLAs: Especially from onsite & IT support, very responsive with resolutions to issues & bugs. 

- Wide range of assortments : Very comprehensive and still growing assortments of products and brands geared towards the future. 

- Good tech system : Data, analytics, module systems are very dynamic and detailed. One of the best dashboards and platforms I ever used.

- Empowerment : Contrary to the beliefs that Lazada is top-down, I wish to clarify it's not. Clusters are given empowerment and encouraged to propose ideas and solutions to campaigns.

- Good management : The C levels know the ground, and are very responsive to competitors and macro economics factors.
Cons:
Not really cons to me, but here it goes :

- Frequent OTs: That's because of the number of campaigns ran and how we wanted to assist sellers to succeed.

- Work-life balance: Due to frequent OTs. However, I want to emphasize this can still be juggled well, if we prioritised our work properly and maturely.

Summary: Wouldn't wish my experience here on my worst enemy
Pros:
- Amazing colleagues on the ground - supportive teams who become true friends
- Nice office space relative to what else is out there. Nice pantry, free snacks, soda machine 
- Fun activities during mega campaigns
- Salary comes in on time
- Good fringe benefits
Cons:
- NEPOTISM - If you want to grow, you need to be BFF's with upper management. You can work insanely hard for years and fail to be promoted in place of people who are buddy buddy with upper management. FORGET ABOUT ANY CAREER GROWTH.

- Close to ZERO work life balance - be prepared to basically sell your soul to the company. Don't expect to have any time for yourself, your family or friends even in the evening. Be prepared for your boss to call you at 12 midnight and ask you for work

- THE TECH IS HORRIBLE - you would think that a company backed by Alibaba would have good tech but you would be wrong. There is very limited data you can look at which makes it almost impossible to do your job

- Pointless middle management - Lazada Singapore puts Category Managers on top of Key Account Managers and all they do is baby sit instead of focus on trying to grow their categories. When Key Account Managers want to execute their work, they can't do it without the Category managers breathing down their necks. This is an example of essentially useless middle management

- No 360 degree feedback during performance reviews

- TOXIC CULTURE OF FEAR and GASLIGHTING

- Lack of direction and strategy - "strategy" changes every few months depending on what Shopee does.

Summary: Not a place for everyone - 5 reasons to join or avoid
Pros:
1. Personal development. Plenty of opportunities to learn about a variety of functions - account management, marketing, logistics, operations, etc. Partially due to an unstructured organization - no clear roles and responsibilities. Requires willingness to take initiative to expand work beyond your job scope. 

2. Societal impact. Ecommerce in South East Asia is still in its early days. Many buyers/sellers are still conducting transactions offline. Much room to shape the development of ecommerce. To make a difference in the lives of millions across the region. Fulfilling experience if you succeed.
Cons:
3. People quality. The rapid growth of ecommerce has resulted in need for rapid hiring/promotion. Speed is prioritized at the expense of quality. Many employees lack relevant functional or management expertise required for their roles/responsibilities. Leads to poorly designed and executed projects. Can be a frustrating experience. You have to be an independent thinker to navigate around limited competency. 

4. Professional development. Superficial process and inadequate transparency during performance reviews. Promotions (or lack of it) can be unsubstantiated. Decision-makers susceptible to confirmation bias - grasping at straws to justify decisions. Exacerbates the lack of functional/management expertise in the company. If objectivity is essential to you, this may not be a company of good fit.

5. Culture. Inconsistency in words and actions. For instance, one advocates accountability, yet avoids any for themselves. Or claims to offer autonomy, yet adopts an authoritarian approach. Will depend on the importance of culture to you or your tolerance towards such.

Pros: INTERESTING and colleagues are encouraging

Summary: Many opportunities to learn and chart your own success
Pros:
- Company is growing fast, therefore there are opportunities that might not immediately exist
- Regular communication are provided and continually encouraging growth, both personally and professionally
- You get to work with top leaders in Alibaba -- smart, collaborative and driven
- You get to chart your own success, navigating through the ambiguous environment
- This is a place you can have limitless opportunities; work in all areas allows deep integration into the business 
- Strong values and culture, which drive purpose-driven objectives
- Always an opportunity to be the change agent, to right areas of development and progress the company forward
- Above market salary, which hinges heavily on employee shares.
Cons:
- No company is perfect. 
- As the company continue to grow, there are many things that are evolving (updating technology, org. structure, formalizing policies, etc.) which are by-products of any growing company. 
- It is important not to be obsessed on what's wrong, but to focus on what is right and the progress (continual improvement) that supports the vision and direction.
- With this growth mindeset, there is always an opportunity to define the future and the role that you play.
-Like any tech companies, the company can be highly complex, and not everyone can succeed in navigating the ambiguity.
-Worklife balance can suffer, but it is the passion of the work, and the purpose that we believe in, that drive employees to put in the longer hours.

Pros:
Lazada must be considered a giant sinking ship. Leaders jump the e-commerce equivalent of the Titanic faster than you can open your eyes. So many executives from Alibaba (the parent company) have come and (a few months later) left again that you would probably need a kilometer long wall to put all their pictures up to admire the Great Wall of Business Failure.
If you ever wanted to drown, this company is for you!

Tremendous leadership issues, tremendous privacy issues, incredibly negative corporate culture, abysmal internal communication, stifling micromanagement, mind-boggling lack of empathy from the so-called leadership, an all-pervading sense of unhappiness at the office.
Even the Titanic had less problems (and, if you remember, most people in that movie died).

Compensation and other benefits level are too different between local staff and expats

Summary: Just another employee that can be replaced
Pros: Free food during mega campaigns
Cons:
1. Alibaba culture.  You are not valued as an employee. You are expected to work and be loyal to the company. If you are not happy in your role, find another job or role within the company. 
2. HR is bad. Their surveys measure happiness within employees but the questions asked are skewed to what's good and what's working. Group CPO Sophie is all talk and no action, she also said in the downhill Q&A that if you are not happy with your manager or your role, you can leave. HRBPs are also not doing their job. No safe environment for employees to provide feedback despite their "openness".
3. Local CEO does not get to know the ground and the employees. If you are not management you will be ignored. After the change in CEO, it has become very hierarchal. 
4. Many VPs and managers are hired because they want more experienced people. But most of the work are very executional which no-one wants to touch. Inexperienced managers as well who do not know how to manage a team, and are only concerned about climbing the ladder. No 360 feedback for employees as well. 
5. People in management are busy fighting their own political war. Promoting people who are on "their side", and if you are willing to do what it takes to be on their side you will be on a fast track for your career.

Pros: All looks good from outside
Cons: Worst company culture to work for, HR are not people partner but rather worst gossiping group and toxic team.  Pretending to be nice to people but really toxic relationships. If you watch Empresses in the palace then you know does it like working in Lazada

Summary: World-class knowledge and technology but culture and innovation is lacking
Pros:
1. Office has a nice view and pantry is well stocked with drinks, snacks and fruits.
2. Fast paced work environment in an exciting e-commerce space.
3. Opportunity to learn from some really smart people from Alibaba.
4. Technology stack is world class and years ahead of others.
5. Many re-organisations to keep things fresh! (This might be a con for some)
Cons:
1. Top heavy with more VPs and managers than ground level working staff leading to many meetings, decks, proposals but nobody left to execute.
2. Too many inexperienced managers with inflated titles leading teams just because they joined back in the early days.
3. Culture is toxic. Toxic but high performing employees are not fired but promoted. Backstabbing to take over projects or to claim credit is common.
4. If you do not speak mandarin, you are disadvantaged as most high level decisions are make in mandarin for efficiency.
5. Decisions will be stuck indefinitely unless you know someone from the Alibaba inner circle (which makes up most of the product and technology teams).
6. No innovation in the product as most features are copied from Tmall/Taobao and not localised to the SEA market.

Pros: Lazada taught me to appreciate the beauty of resigning from my job. I would like to thank them for that. It was one of the happiest days of my life walking away from this company. When you leave Lazada you realize what true freedom means. A big pro!
Cons:
- Every single day that you work for this company must be considered a waste of lifetime. The high turnover rate and the toxic atmosphere at work speak for themselves.
- Leadership at Lazada is defined by intimidation, arrogance and favoritism, as well as questionable ethics.
- Dreadful, virtually non-existent communication within and between teams. I shouldnâ€™t even use the term â€œteamâ€. Teams do not exist in Lazada. You follow orders of your superiors.
- Extreme workload and terrible work-work balance. Yes, youâ€™ve heard correctly: work-work balance. There is no life at Lazada. You are trying to balance work with more work.
- Management doesnâ€™t understand the meaning of the words â€œencouragementâ€ and â€œappreciationâ€. Their idea of rewarding excellent work is to belittle or ignore it and to focus on flaws instead.

Pros: Nothing. Donâ€™t waste your career to join this place. Do not even consider unless you are so desperate.
Cons: Both old and new management treats local staff with utter contempt. Whatâ€™s worst is majority are out of their depth for the roles they are in. Prefers to steal any achievements as they own and throw the contributor off the bus.

Pros:
1. it's resource economy, based on already existing large customer base; so you can be confident even if you do wrong things or don't do anything.
2. ability to learn from internal tech stack
Cons:
1. actually most of people can't work in a distributed team; no way to make them do their part of job unless you can come to their desk with a baseball beat.
2. bureaucracy is overwhelming, for simple things like work permit for foreign employees or business trip, you have to fill tons of forms; corporate bureaucracy is more than state bureaucracy.
3. dependency on alibaba's proprietary technologies, which are neither well documented nor supported.     
4. related to #1, most of guys from CN have very bad memory and can't keep attention (probably due to 11hr working day), one have to ask them the same things multiple time, while they prefer to answer very briefly, like "?" or "...."

Pros:
Good and smart people in local (SG) office.
Many problems and challenges to solve, never boring.
Good food during campaigns
Decent promotions for lower echelons recently.
Do see local CEO making effort to improve employee satisfaction.
Alot of opportunities for growth if you work hard.
Things happening every quarter to attempt to solve the problems in the country.
Cons:
Bad work life balance, especially during campaigns.
KPIs supersede everything to the point of ridiculousness; you are compared against your teammates, other countries teams, and KPIs can be things that are always unattainable.
Administration work is painful, requiring similar (yet different) updates of multiple slides, etc to local team, regional team and CEO. Ultimate waste of time. 
Many of the systems in-house replaced by Chinese products that are annoying and inferior.
Plans and projects keep changing ; no clear direction from the A team often times. Regional and local direction forever misaligned. 
Products rolled out by tech teams always incomplete and not tailored for local context ; waste of time and ineffective + causes administrative pain.
Everything is sacrificed for GMV, with campaigns far too close resulting in projects being delayed in between.
Too many middle management and too little people at the bottom that allows for things to move.

- Hire right, do not just hire high.

Pros: Interesting projects, some intelligent and nice people (though these people generally don't thrive in the culture)
Cons: The 3-month probationary period is generally abused here as a cover for bad hiring decisions or to protect bad managers. As a new person, things are always going to be difficult, but in Lazada it will be even more difficult because of the toxic culture. With the instability within the organization and the high turnover rate, I have heard and seen numerous instances where promises made to get people into the company were broken the moment the person entered the company or a person's team gets restructured within a few weeks of the person entering into the company and no effort is expended to find another alternative for the new person because they are easy to get rid of while on probation. Everybody tells you that you have to be prepared for changes in this company, but I think it is important to be aware of how these changes can impact the promises made to you and your assumptions of the job when entering this organization.

Pros: Growing fast and competitive salary

Summary: Started from being the best job to the worst
Pros: I made great friends and work was really fun before we were acquired by Alibaba.
Cons: We were acquired by Alibaba and management was off. One of the worst M&As ever, should be a HBS case study.

Pros: E-commerce will remain a strong growth market in the region.
Cons:
1. Directive culture, be prepared to act as yes-men. Face time is valued over productivity. 
2. Every new initiative, process, strategy etc is now cut copy paste from Alibaba. Regardless whether this actually works in the local market space and culture. Unfortunately, mostly it does not. 
3. Many VPs and above are rewarded based on their ability to play politics and find favour with the right (Alibaba) executive leaders, instead of on their work achievements. Basic Management capabilities are shockingly lacking in a lot of senior folks.
4. No respect for the individual employees, you are expected to dedicate yourself  24/7 to your work â€˜familyâ€™. 
5. You may not be very successful if youâ€™re not a mandarin speaker. Entire departments now converse, hold their meetings/ send emails solely in Chinese.

Pros: Good learning ground, challenges your ability.
Cons: The management has no directions. No progression/ growth. Top-down managing style. HOF lacks empathy when it comes to managing her own people. Doesn't listen.

Summary: Less than 1 star. Join at your own risk.

Cons:
Long list. Not sure as to where to start. 
I work in the security team. 
A lot of Alibaba secondees have joined Lazada security, and they really have zero knowledge about security. Arrogant people from Alibaba treat Lazadians with apathy and hatred. 
This company has lost its charm and once Amazon picks up pace in this market, people will easily goodbye to Lazada.
Do not trust the so called positive reviews. Grapevine has it that Lazada has hired senior PR and branding folks and now they are putting in 'good' reviews inorganically.
Think 100 times before you accept their offer. You will regret.

Summary: Join only if you love toxic
Pros: Wanted to share the pros of RedMart only since Lazada has integrated with RedMart glassdoor reviews. I would definitely more than happy to encourage people to join RedMart because the culture is just that great. Now this integration happened, I can only say the whole company Lazada is in a mess. No proper processes, directions are always changing/changed suddenly, many people are leaving because of this toxic environment.
Cons: 0% transparency, 0% proper communications. Always delaying important projects but yet ask to do so many unnecessary works.

Pros:
Flat hierarchy
Late work start time
Cons:
No work life balance
No transparency 
No succession planning from managers

Pros:
Business growth is fantastic. They can't seem to mess this up no matter how much they try. Growth in the market just keeps the company going despite one bad decision after another.

Very difficult to find such big responsibilities and roles in such a large business at even early stages of your career (still even got some C levels in their 30s)
Cons:
Complete Chinese takeover. One by one entire functions are replaced by Chinese nationals. Especially in tech and product, meetings and emails just go out in Chinese and the rest of us have to try to do our jobs using Google translate. Senior managent say they will limit the number of Chinese nationals they bring to Singapore, so 3 months later they just open two offices directly in China to get around the policy. If you are not Chinese you cannot have a long term career. Just put your head down and don't argue. 

Decisions not made based on data or analysis. Whatever the highest ranking person made up on the spot after five minutes becomes the strategy. People under them will not try to advise them based on any actual numbers or help provide insights. This is how they destroyed Redmart. Alibaba said they need to integrate Redmart after a short meeting, so they immediately did it without taking any time to think about customer impact, how to do it smoothly or properly. Execution without insight. Within 3 months Redmart was dead.

No regard for what's right for the business. Follow the KPI your boss told you at all costs, even if it destroys business and customer experience. It doesn't matter what kind of business you have, following a KPI blindly without judgement is always bad for business in the long run. People will not do things that are easy, quick and good for the business just because their KPI didn't say it.

The worst HR function I've ever seen in my life. They don't care at all about employee welfare. Just a mouthpiece of cooperate propaganda. They tried to hire HR executives from mature companies but the last one resigned after 3 weeks of seeing how the team is run.

Summary: Bad culture, bad environment, inconsiderate management
Pros: Convenient location in CBD, however management frowns on anyone who leaves before 630pm.
Cons:
Top management is unethical and dis-ingeniousness - they say pleasant things outwardly to the public, but give veiled threats to employees in private that want to propose change. 

Management also imports foreign nationals from Alibaba to force change which are against local business and cultural norms. They tacitly punish those who do not support these changes.

The company also promotes a toxic work commitment, and expects almost immediate responses via an in-house messaging app - even on weekends and public holidays. When this issue of work-life balance is brought up, management says outwardly that they want all employees to have proper rest, but C-level executives regularly send messages, emails and updates during rest hours (even as late as 12 midnight).

Pros: You learn a lot.
Cons: Most of the time, effort goes unnoticed.

dont hope to learn from the so-called leaders here - most of them have no idea whats going on and only know how to perform lip service and parrot what their bosses say. 

ever since the takeover by alibaba, local headcount are treated more like requirements HR needs to fulfill in order to get more EPs for the chinese / foreigners to come in. if you dont speak chinese, expect yourself to fall behind.

favoritism is rampant and blatantly obvious.

Summary: Good place for one to build foundation

1) Fun and youthful environment . Makes you feel young once again.

2) Opportunity to learn different scopes (also not exactly a good thing especially when you have to double-hat)

Cons:
1) Like to launch features/projects hastily and not devote attention to it once some new is launched. Poorly planning.

2) Lack of communication between different functions and also regional to local teams.

3) Double-hatting and high attrition rate is normal here.

4) Tech-driven but the resources are not focused on automating some of the daily necessities. It makes the work too manual especially when different systems don't interact with each other.

5) Slow career progression .

6) Too many unnecessary calls/meetings that eats into productivity.

7) Company would rather spend money to hire VP and above than to hire non-management level positions to split the workload. 

8) Some of the Senior Managers to Chief-level staff are good at "smoking" their way through when they know nothing.

Summary: Top-down HR culture, outdated HR processes being forced in the company
Pros:
Fast growing e-commerce and company is one of the fastest growing.

CEO and commercial leaders have ambitious growth plan and it actually seems possible that it can be realised.

Management in commercial divisions is good, though it could be better supported by the top management to have sufficient resources for them.

For HR aspirants: This is the place for you if:
- you like to work in organisations where who-you-know matters far more than what-you-accomplish, and want to be skilled at playing politics.
- are good at showing a sense of urgency in body language, are great at making consultancy-style presentations, even if it does not have focus.
- want the brand name of Alibaba group on your CV.. and don't mind doing anything that comes with it.
- are young, under 6 years of experience, and wants to hold senior job titles without actual seniority.
Cons:
In HR: Top-down and directive work culture that is operated behind a veil of being a family.

Senior HR leaders are unable to develop focus to address most pressing needs and gaps of business. Most senior leaders set the tone of being aggressive, assert authority, and take little accountability for their own poor planning.

Has attracted people in HR who 'service' with lots of activities.. but do not know how to develop great HR initiatives.

Urgent activities all the time actually is a reflection of poor decision making and  planning by HR leaders. They show confidence, make many powerpoint slides, organise many group events, instagram photo taking, etc. But very little actual contribution to business or its people.

Summary: So much potential , but deficient culture and rampant colonialism/racism

Trendy industry, developing the sector in South East Asia
Cons:
Outright racism, neo-colonialism across all of the countries
Jr. staff are just treated as cogs
German, Italian or French? Good to go. Else, you need to be more much qualified to receive same compensation.
Project are generally short sighted and execution is based on experiences from abroad, but not particularly understanding of the markets. Competitors with more localized strategy will outgrow Lazada. Eg. Shopee.
Overemphasis on vouchers to buy growth. 
Too many ex-consultants and to few techies and product managers.

Summary: Great place to work, can do better with local management
Pros: Great empowerment from immediate boss
Cons: Management doesn't trust their staff enough

Pros:
Good team work and collaboration at the local  venture/Tech/Product/Finance/HR level. 
People work as 1 team and help each other to make the business initiatives, programs and systems roll-out a success.  Local teams has deep in-depth knowledge of their various business functions, what goes well and what can be improved (by what, by how, by when).  
Good  and stronger HR team after Alibaba has helped to re-structure the organization and observe better corporate and social responsibilities.  
Product and Tech teams shared good knowledge and experience on the e-commerce ecosystem. Most of them are keen and proactive to learn SEA culture and business.
Things are fast paced but if you have a supportive team and manager, everything will work out well as long as willing to learn and work hard.
Cons:
Lack of trust and respect from Lazada "old timers people managers" who humiliate staff /even peers publicly whenever things  do not go according to "their way".  In my day to day work,  I encountered situations where these people think they are experts in all functional areas (when they are not) and start to finger point at other teams eg Tech/Finance/Product/Engineering whenever projects/plans hit into issues and  potentially impact their KPIs. Observe managers jumping into conclusions without listening to their staff explanations and giving teams a chance to explain.

Most people in certain regional functions do not know  E-commerce ecosystem and logistics operations.  Even the so called heads do not have deep expertise.
Knowing very limited small pieces here and there, they try to act like "experts" by doing some presentations with some nice diagrams,  mass blasting emails to copy every CEO/COO thinking they are smart and  try to market themselves,boasting when the project has not even started and no buy-in from all stakeholders yet.  With incomplete business requirements and not bothering to work hard to find out details /learning from the ground,  such projects will never be successful.

(2) Nice office 
(3) Alot of smart people working here
Cons:
(1) Dont call yourself a People Team if you cant even look after your own people. Speaks volume if leadership team has internal turmoil and in fighting. Even outsiders can tell us whats happening.
(2) Doesnt do what it preach about going global and growing local talents. What is said since Alibaba take over and implemented is completely different. 
(3) Politics everywhere and you'll spend 80% of your time navigating politics instead of valuing adding.
(4) Not alot of people survive past 1 - 2 years. If they can, they usually are numb or play the right cards.
(5) Being in the constant changes and reorg, you will question whats important in your life and start prioritising your important values. Money, power over health and family or vice versa.

Cons:
Leadership is very weak in every aspect from top to bottom. New leaders can't take strong decisions and have zero knowledge of people management.

Pros: Nice environment, nice partner,  good salary
Cons: No, I don't see any.

Pros:
I can admit, it has been a very bumpy ride. Working with so many people. Moving from local team to regional team. Seeing so many newbies becoming professionals. Experiencing managers who sacrifice their own staff to survive in the company at expense of others. 

What I find very upsetting is that majority of company problems come from its own leadership, not competition. I have never seen or imagined that so many high level profiles getting fired or booted, and not just during restructuring, it has been like from the beginning. And all of that for a reason. Company was founded from the foreign capital and nobody from leadership cared about making right decisions, they only cared about their own well being.

It really feels like internal conflict is the biggest obstruction on the way of success.

Also it is hard  to give a fair judgement for all 4 years, as some years were very bad and some were good. I would give 3 starts, because right now company has new leadership, with old leaders are moving away. Let's hope this will be a positive change.

You have everything you need to learn e-commerce:
Freedom to do a good job or a "bad job"
Freedom from your line manager, because he doesnâ€™t care if you do good or bad.
Access to metrics and data you need to develop yourself into professional.
You can meet talented experts and occasionally amazing managers.
Cons:
Politics surround you from the first day: local versus regional, sales versus operations versus, us versus them.
Nobody cares about your achievements: if you expect to be recognized or promoted, well you will never get any recognition and to get promotion you have to be reporting to an experienced manager in the first place.
Working day and night: it is not just overtimes, it is work on the weekends too.
Keep your passion in check: I have never seen so many people burn out anywhere else.
Do not rely on trust: you can get fired by your manager, just because he or she doesnâ€™t like you.
