Summary: Great place to develop yourself and achieve more
Pros:
Colleagues are very friendly and helpful
Tasks are ambitious and not standard. Plus you are making a really huge impact here (company is working in 11 countries ya know)
Technology stack is up to date and you'll be in demand after having experience here.
Medical insurance + a lot of other small benefits. Paid overtimes in case they are really needed. Great company culture
Company is not stagnating, something new is always happening - new features, new projects. Its a challenging environment, but if you are a warrior, you'll belong in Lazada
Cons:
I think that not all processes are really established well. Sometimes its hard to find who is responsible for something, and you'll need to chase several people to find a person in charge. People are helpful though)
Structural changes are quite often. I guess it was happening because our department was growing - i switched 3 teams during my work here. For some people it could be tiresome to adapt to new people in their team each time something changes

Pros:
Multi-culture, international working environment. 
People are almost young and friendly, dynamic. 
Work overseas, business trip...
Working time is flexible.
Cons: Nothing to share now :)

Summary: Messy, racist and insensitive culture with no transparency and respect
Pros: Biggest e-commerce in South East Asia
Cons:
Messy, Top down, biased and insensitive work culture where your value depends on your race and proximity to and acceptance by Chinese bosses. If you are Chinese from mainland your chances are higher else good luck! 

Merit based roles and responsibilities are largely non existent. People have been given VP and SVP titles without any reason or experience and they canâ€™t even manage themselves let alone manage a team.

There is nothing inspirational and motivating with the culture and is just a bit hustle to chase deadline after deadline without reflecting what is working and what is not.

Pros: Good if you want advance your experience as you will have a lot of project and impossible KPI on your hands
Cons:
- Bad management try to micromanage everything
- Boss is not supportive, always ready to backstab you
- Boss never give solution when you hit the wall, they always expect you to solve every problem yourself, sometimes even their problem

Pros:
The company always changing, but for me changing is good, tech stack can be changed within year event half of year
Good environment, nice people, a good place to motivate your self
Cons: Changing is good but not always suitable for the employee in some case

Pros:
- Work with many nationality
- High Salary
- Have a good career path
Cons: Have to work by oneself, No one know the whole system exactly.

Pros: Very promising industry, with great platform and technology; top leaders are great
Cons: Some leaders can be much better

Pros:
Decent benefits, exposure to Alibaba technologies and methodologies.
Top industry firm, good learning opportunity.
Cons:
Colonialism culture: your feedback is rarely heard as the Chinese will do it their way instead. Alibaba brags about "globalization" but for most things, they chose to follow the quickest and easiest path instead of what is right.

HR processes are highly wasteful and slow, skilled people are leaving and what left behind are people who have cling on the corporate structure to survive, afraid of disruptive changes.

Lack of openness, information are shared only if they are positive news. Bad press are well hidden and not being publicly addressed until they are overdue. Many of townhalls, meal-with-ceo session are discontinued as leadership unable to receive negative feedbacks. Email announcements are sometimes in full Chinese without consideration for employees of 6 non-chinese-speaking employees.

Lack of sense of ownership, direction of product, tech and even business are often made by Chinese, copied from success of Taobao or Tmall and re-applied to SEA market without proper handover, proper training. This lead to ownership of many of key domains being shifted to teams in Hang Zhou and Shenzhen instead of local team. People felt lack of responsibility, lack of impact and left disappointed for months.

Lack of proper training, handover, on-boarding processes.

Pros:
Great industry. E-commerce has huge potential in Asia
Great Leaders. Pierre is super sharp, smart and effective, with great leadership to engage people, while still being a humble leader.
Great Colleagues. People works here are generally young and energetic. Enjoy work with smart colleagues
Cons:
Set up and communication between Regional and country are not effective. 
Some people are reluctant to the changes and spread negative attitude

Pros:
-  peer level colleagues are nice
- place to learn e-commerce and be independent as insufficient support is given
 - Have lots of drinking parties
Cons:
- Promises from senior management are unaccountable
 - Senior management would rather hire someone external with 0 knowledge in this industry  as VP or higher level instead of promoting and  growing own talents. Ideally those different backgrounds VPs should bring new perspectives, ideas or changes , yet failing to do so and assimilated into the existing poor management culture: work in silos, only focus on own KPI instead of looking at big picture & overall's good. Standard  mindset is like " I don't care your difficulties, SOP or roadblocks, it's not my business, i only want this target to be happened"
- No collaborations between departments. 
 - Ignore / Not evaluating business impact on operations when launching many tech projects. Front liners have to clear up all mess due to this kind of short-sighted projects.
 - No post modem culture.

Pros: Fast moving, lots of experiences
Cons: Unclear process and roadmap, better move after 1+ year

Pros: Lots to do if you are a workaholic, international environment, a good stepping stone
Cons: where to start? I guess the turnover rate says it all.

Summary: Benefits to Locals vs Foreigners (Rants of a Local)
Pros:
More foreigners and Tripartite Guidelines seems to be ignored.

Hire 1 and Get 1 free ! Get a job under EP and spouse gets a free job as dependent. Then EP person move out to better company but still enjoying all the lazada benefits through spouse !

Lot of foreigners using Lazada as a spring board to move to other companies in Singapore.

Foreigners rejecting job offers even after being offered 8K per annum and HR pacifying them with more pay while locals are being bargained with their asking pay to settle for lower pay ! This can happen only in Singapore. Pathetic HR and HR is interested in the welfare of Foreigners than Locals.

Locals accept lower pay as any pay is a good pay for them. So advice to locals is to demand higher pay even though HR try to bargain with you. Always note that you are being offered less than foreigners in the first instance.
Cons:
Locals are shunned and considered only for low level positions from Analyst to Senior Associate positions. While you see some in mid level positions, will be hard to see in upper level positions from VP to Executive VP, leave alone the C level. 

Max at least smiles whenever he see a Lazadian in office or outside (whatever stress he has been in) while Pierre love to show his poker  face. He may smile if he see a french but definitely not at others :-( 

Sorry Pierre. Thought that you will give some importance for locals as you are 50% local but you still seem to live in your french diaspora which is evident from your recent appointments of heads for LeL.

Foreigners with less experience lands in plum roles with higher pay. Looks like skin colour matters.

Pros: Plenty of rooms to explore
Cons: Day to day tasks are sometimes are not aligned with jobdesc

Pros:
- Taking care employees like family (My Team, I don't know the others)
- By this environment, this pulled my unknown performance which I can do. I can find myself more, I knew more what else I can do.
Cons:
- Too many calories food during dinner or special meals also sugar carbonate drinks too.
- Internal changes happened quite often, however I hope this will be good structure now.

Summary: Good Company to work with, leading south east Asia eCommerce market.
Pros:
- Use new tech stack, lots of learning. Work on many projects. 
- Best work life balance, can work from home too.
- Stable job as company growing every year exponentially
- Work culture good, lots of parties, fun
- Good Company Benefits (8K for paternity/maternity and many others)
Cons:
- Company now run by alibaba so most of the work is being driven by them from China.
- Lots of travels (if required in your work)
- Company still has startup culture so lots of changes in projects, role, work.

Pros: Gain lots of experiences in short time
Cons: Always working.  IM (Ding talk) is always humming. Ppl don't really respect personal time here, but maybe this is Alibaba's working style.

Pros: Young and vibrant team mates
Cons: No direction throughout the organisation

Summary: Didn't believe glassdoor reviews till I joined
Pros:
- Colleagues have nice personalities in general

- Decent compensation

- Can tell HR is trying their best to improve the company but it is difficult to feel convinced when most of them cannot speak english fluently
Cons:
- Top-down approach. Every â€œideaâ€ from senior management is Tmall did this, Taobao did that. Aliâ€™s mindset is we are successful in China so do listen to us. No organic innovation

- Competitor obsessed, always stalking what Shopee is doing

- Forced to use Aliâ€™s tech stack in mandarin with zero effort to localise it. In-house data visualization software is the most rudimentary I have ever seen and extremely painstaking to use. Exporting data is such a hassle given the tight data security thus operations are inefficient

- Majority of business managers do not know basic SQL/Python/R yet they work at a tech firm 

- Some roles are routine and can actually be outsourced to contract staff

- Whole set of C-suite executives for each mini venture/business unit making the entire org chart convoluted

Summary: So far so good, try hard though
Pros:
Lots of responsibility so learned a lot, tiring though, good for young people to learn
Quite good benefit policy and facilities
Cons: A lot of changes recently

Pros:
Huge industry potential -- E-commerce industry in SEA is a blue sea, and grows rapidly. Lazada is the strongest player in the local market. Therefore if you are interested in the industry, Lazada is a good place to start. 
Fast paced working environment --- It could be very challenging sometimes. but you can learn a lot in a short period of time, and develop your ability faster than in a mature corporate. 
Colleagues are nice --- I feel most of Lazadians ( not those from Alibaba) are respectful and smart. Even though sometimes there are conflicts or argument,  but that's normal. Lazadians always work together to find a solution in a structural way. and they try their best to not hurt others.
Cons:
Before Alibaba:
Bad HR management: Career path is very unclear. HR team is not doing anything to help employees to grow. 
Unclear roadmap: seems like we were trying a lot of different things. But the team doesn't have clear visibilities about where we were heading to.

After Alibaba:
Still Bad HR Management -- I don't see any changes expect they keep replacing local employees with Alibaba persons, some of whom cannot even speak English properly.  
Roadmap -- I still don't know. I don't know why I'm working hard for this company. Which direction we are heading to. Why my job is important ( if it isï¼‰....... Before Alibaba, with all the cons, I still choose to stay with Lazada. It's because I share the value of the company. I'm not sure if I still share the same value with Alibaba. 
Working Environment: A lot worse. Many people from Alibaba(especially the commercial side) have no idea about what respect is. I can tell Alibaba has no clue about how to run a multinational company. As other comments mentioned, the most frequent words you can hear is :" in T-mall, we always..." You can see they are basically copying everything from T-mall, Taobao to Lazada. However,   Lazada is not T-mall or Taobao. The culture is different, the market is different, the suppliers are also different. So stop copying everything, and learn from the locals. And speaking of professionalism, I deeply feel Lazadians are way more professional and efficient than Ali persons. ( SOP and rules sometimes mean nothing to Alibaba persons)

Summary: The company culture was good, but the job was stagnant and lacked opportunity was growth
Pros: Good benefits, stable working hours, relaxed work environment
Cons: Minimal opportunities for growth, lack of visibility on what others are doing which leads to low sense of team camaraderie

Pros: Famous starup / Ecom among South East Asia
Cons: Poor interview management, no follow up calls, ignore candidates !

Pros: Dynamic working environment. International teams. Opportunities for travel
Cons: Career development not yet a focus

Pros: flexible , multicultural coworkers, result-driven company
Cons: no career development, low salary

Summary: I will Never work for a Chinese company again
Pros: If you are senior developer but do not want to code anymore, join Lazada. It will be easier and comfortable.
Cons:
Nothing new to learn. There is no freedom to take up new technologies and push ideas. Everything seems restrictive. 
Total top-down approach. No clear career path visible. The titles seem to be arbitrary.

Summary: Great place for graduates if you want to learn
Pros:
People are generally all very nice and friendly bunch

Young and vibrant people
Cons:
Unrealistic timelines for goals

Steep learning curve, they expect you to dive right in and be able to assimilate to the role

Pros:
Great environment and working culture
Company Shuttle
Great food
Cons: Very demanding hours and tucked-away location

Summary: a good place to join, when it stabilises
Pros:
if you can pick things up fast, you will learn a lot of skills

flat hierarchy

teammates will be your family
Cons:
management is unbelievably experienced, it's very very clear favouritism is still at play. can you imagine 3/4 of commercial directors are non local, tell me how you are supposed to win the market when they clearly do not have the contacts nor right experience. 

it feels rather "communist", like in China? there is a lot of propaganda and trying to shield us from the bitter truth that really, no one knows what the heck is going on. 

titles are joke, everyone seems to be c of something, vp of something that too many heads are butting and who's the one who suffers? those doing the executional work.

if you want to join, please purchase a second phone. your data is not safe, your personal life is not safe and your privacy comes last to business needs.

Pros:
Good work life balance + work from home
Good culture 
Staff sales!
Cons:
No clear progression
Location is far but there are shuttle buses.

Pros: Management is aware of the abysmal Glasdoor ratings: the new CEO himself asked the whole company in a town hall to come leave positive reviews. We may overtake FoxConn anytime soon.
Cons: Management solution for bad Glasdoor reviews is to blame disgruntled employees for them and ask the happy campers to come here and praise the new administration. Take all positive comments from Aug 27 onwards with a pinch of salt.

Pros: Only because it is a Alibaba subsidiary company!
Cons: Never concerning of People but called People team.  The HR in Singapore office only concern the senior management, doesnâ€™t listen to or care of the general staffs opinions, or just ignore you.

Pros:
- Great colleagues, young atmosphere, people with lot of energy
- Good to learn from Alibaba, the expert about ecommerce
- Company cares about results not age / race. Much more exciting than most companies in Malaysia
Cons: - Very expectations for the staff, no time to slow down

Summary: Lazada: Slow as big corporate but act like a startup company
Pros:
- People are young and energetic
- The company has a lot of mess to clean up -> More work for people who love to work
- Flexibility: Nobody is very clear about what they are doing so, of course, you can do anything. No real goal, no real method to measure the success of a project, no real roadmap, and deadline...
Cons:
- Lazada is considered slow for the e-commerce industry. The speed you see is just the speed of ruining things when employees do not understand what they are doing. Then smarter people have to clean the mess up. This keeps happening so smart people do not have time to build smart things. Then smart people leave (and they should).
- No innovation, creativity is killed here. 
- People are put in the job that they do not have relevant skills or experience -> that rule all the projects they manage and also ruin the team spirit regardless of the level of the ruiner. 
- Alibaba came and made things worse. They have no experience in ruling a multinational company, but they think they do. The communication effectiveness between Alibaba and Lazada is equal 0. Alibaba team also has no sense of cultural difference. 
- Alibaba is changing all the non south-east Asian employees to Alibaba staff. They don't understand that the cultural diversity should be more than just Chinese and other countries but a good mix of people for a good mix of the points of view on anything.
- Communication is too mixed up and people get different information from different channels.

Pros: When we finally moved to AXA towers we had a nicer office set-up, proper restrooms and nice pantry that's stocked well
Cons: Everything. The leaders are verbally abusive. Crazy working hours, they try to bribe you with 'buffet' food to work overnight at the office especially for sales days. Seniors all play politics so if you're not BFFs with them, you won't last here.

Summary: Ever Changing - Always on the Move
Pros:
You wonâ€™t be bored, a lot of exciting projects always around, campaign with the major focus on nimber of items sold. 
Competition between ecommerces are real and giving the drive to each project.
Cons: Regional product team making development to be a bit slow and not aligning with local teams are always a pain point.

Pros: Opportunity to work with different nationalities; Internationalization
Cons:
Lazada was once a great place to work in. Employees were being heard, supported and have the capability to think outside of the box and explore.

But since the Chinese management has entered the picture, Lazada became a place of horror. These Chinese Leadership/Management thinks that they know everything and that we (old Lazada employees) doesnt know anything. Collaboration is one key for overall success of a team/company, but Chinese team do not think nor show this. They know everything, so why listen to small time old Lazada employees, right? This has made everyone, including myself to feel degraded and of course, it affects the morale of the employees.

Also, Alibaba's goal is towards Globalization, right? Maybe, that is just for a show as it turns out, once we have China teams on top, they do everything in their own language; business, product and tech! It really doesnt add up.

Pros:
- Lots of new things to self training
- Working under huge pressure to iron your brain and spirit
- Young, open and free working environment
Cons:
- Bad HR management: no clear procedure, a few training, no clear career path and development program for people...
- Over-time almost of the time
- Start up then no standard processes, a bit messy

Summary: Great culture but changing as we speak
Pros:
Great talent
Lovely culture 
Ambitious but now a bit structured and slow post-buyout
Cons: Favortism and are now treating some older employees badly

Pros: Was interesting to work before it was sold to Ali
Cons: Weak management,  frequently changing managers

Pros:
Really good work culture and really smart people. 
Has a good work-life balance
Cons:
Intern Stipend.
Not that great benefits for employees.

Summary: Not good for lower level employee
Pros:
- fast pace company, not boring
- dynamic
Cons:
- KPI driven 
- Work life balance does not exist
- Insufficient coaching from superior
- Inconsistent in management's decision
- Salary and rank do not match: you can have people at different level but having about the same pay
- You will not know how your performance is assessed and how increment is decided

Pros:
- You can learn many new things if you are willing to work 24/7
- You can get better offer at Shopee
- Alibaba company name in your CV
- If you are very lucky your line manager and your HR will care about you
Cons:
This company is a monstrosity. People suffer from weak management and bad HR. Every week people keep joining and leaving in large numbers. Not all HR are bad in Lazada, but good HR canâ€™t stay long, they get pushed out. My recruiter and many other in Lazada Vietnam left to Shopee for the same reason, because of horrible HR leadership.
- Lots of lies, every month management tells one thing and later does opposite
- No Tet salary bonus
- Horrible working hours because of poor planning, everything is done last minute
- Low level veterans of the company are treated like trash
- Disrespectful leadership starting from top to bottom
- Nobody will want to teach you anything here
- Very poor skills of middle management
- Very poor recruitment, hired managers do not have good experience
- Aggressive and political culture, nobody cares about anybody
- No career path above senior associate for locals
- Terrible appraisal system, if you manager is strict you will never get anything no matter how hard you work
- No business communications to employees except fancy happy emails, our bonus was bad because company did bad, but nobody told what was the goal and result
- Half year delayed bonuses, half year delayed salary increments, half year delayed promotions. Catchup payments were delayed as well.
- Many empty promises by old and new leadership
- You will be asked for your ideas and suggestions, but those will be ignored afterwards
- Horrible skills of senior HR
- Many employees are fired and many forced to leave, because their managers leave
- No discounts or any other benefits to buy on Lazada

Pros: High-paying, close to mrt, good work timing
Cons: Badwork culture, poor management and staff

Pros:
Very good career opportunity after Alibaba invested, lot's of changes happening, fast pace.
Able to learn from super  experienced ecommerce expert from Taobao
Cons:
Language is a challenge
Lots of travel

Pros:
- Fast pace company
- Casual working dress code
Cons:
- Promotion is highly dependent on skin colour and age (for Asian). Most the wetern people are young and hold the top position of the company but when young Asian opt for promotion is always being told that the age is too young and not senior enough
- Lack of appreciation toward support department such as Finance and HR. Always ignore the request from Finance and even override the Finance SOP if there is an instruction from top managment
- If everything is perfectly done, no promotion is granted. If you resigned, issue happen, more people get hired to solve the issue which previously handled by one person,  those people will get promoted. Tips to promote - don't get thing done perfectly as this will give an impression to the reviewer that you are not doing anything. If you given a chance to resolve the issue, make sure the issue grow bigger and involve more party before you resolved it. Or else, if you resolve it very fast, reviewer will think that this is a small issue.

Pros: Good, have a lot of popularity
Cons: Na. nothing so negative about

Pros:
Dynamic environment
International exposure
Multi culture
Technology driven
Cons:
Unstructured and unclear direction
Boss tends to "run away" from responsibilities and throwing everything to subordinates

Summary: Company with a lot of potential
Pros:
- Can work with the brightest minds not only in SEA, but also in China
- Fast-paced, great for people who love challenges
- Current management team possesses the "been there, done it* mindset. Most are successful and are good mentors
- Fantastic leverage on the experience and expertise of Alibaba colleagues
Cons:
- Very high turnover currently, as company is in transition and not everyone can keep up with the pace.
- Unclear communication at times, as management team is still learning about SEA culture
- Long working hours, due to the drive for success

Pros: For ecommerce industry, one of the best learning ground. Gives you immense experience.
Cons: Over worked with low pay. Achievements are not recognise by upper management. Can be political at times.

Pros:
1. Standard Salary
2. Multicultural working environment
3. The chance to learn new technology related to e-commerce
Cons:
1. As a startup company still doesn't have a firm work culture
2. Top management comes from MBA fresh graduates, doesn't have good leadership and mature management. They are grumpy and bad-tempered.
3. No work/life balance
4. Use low fare airlines in a trip and bad accommodation

Pros: - Because your boss is not around, so you're given flexibility in terms of arriving and leaving work
Cons:
- The management team are not aligned on priorities
- Confusion in KPIs 
- Lack of communication of change in KPIs so everyone is working and focusing on different items 
- The system is redundant in terms of IT, Leave, Reimbursement and Travel
- Only travel by budget air and even if non-budget air is cheaper, they will still insist on buying you expensive budget air flights
- Inflexible working situation

Pros:
- Fast moving
- Dynamic tech team 
- Process driven
- Front seats to the new world of commerce
Cons:
- Little work-life balance
- Bug fixing happens 90% of the time

Summary: Lack of flexibility and question the effectiveness of endless meetings
Pros:
Backing of Alibaba give the public highly positive confidence to the ecommerce business.
Free flow of coke, crackers and fruits.
Cons:
Zero work life balance.  Compare to the past, Lazada is now highly inflexible. Management needs to adjust their expectations and give the working staff a breather.
The regional team is expected to fly every week. You have to because the management said you are not doing your work if you sit at your desk. 
Everyday, there are daily 9am meetings and weekly meetings of various sorts where you are expected to attend. Every day analyse data and share action steps the next day. If you are not present in these meetings, the management will question.
If this is not enough, over the weekends, there would be emails on meeting schedules coming in for the coming weeks. There are endless of group chats where messages fly in every moment, 24-7 with endless questioning from the bosses and needing immediate response. 
The regional and country teams are both stressed, overwhelmed and exhausted.

Pros:
New management seems strategic, but old management seems misaligned.
Some passionate people about the business
Cons:
Direction and changes are not aligned. Different messages.
Communication to ground need to be improved.
Feeling a bit loss for the brand

Summary: Strong Chinese culture after Alibaba took over
Pros: The office is at a very high-end building right in city centre. As Lazada aim to be a tech company, a lot of data is available so if you like numbers and transparent results, you can dig out insight for yourself.
Cons:
A typical 1-man-show culture with everyone runs at CEO's orders (the Chinese CEO from Alibaba). Since the Alibaba management took over, many ppl have left the company due to ineffective leadership (not sure if it's Alibaba intention to let ppl go by themselves).

Everyone got to install 2 apps (1 for chat and the other for VPN authentification, conference call) which can track your location instantly. The boss can use it to see where you are, if you come to work late, if you are at home or doctor's if you file a sick leave.

Summary: One of the worst companies you can imagine
Pros: International environment, growing regional business
Cons:
This can be broken down into 2 areas. Before Alibaba took over, the Lazada senior management was incredibly unprofessional, aggressive, hostile and frankly, just not qualified. It was a nightmare to work at Lazada and do meaningful, proper work but a few championed through despite the numerous issues to try to build up something decent. 

With Alibaba management the hope was that things would become more professional, informed and lift the bar. Sadly things got even worse. People demoted, teams crushed or replaced over night. I say this having personally raised up and discussed these issues collaboratively in 1-1 with all snr management prior and current at CPO, CTO even CEO level. 

No clarity ever offered about future plans, projects and lack of strategy getting even worse (hard to believe). And ofcourse everything became blatently copying Chinese tmall and Alibaba apps. Even much more so than before the takeover. So zero initiatief or intellect needed, just do as you are told and work 24/7. Don't question anything. It is clear that the Chinese way of working means there is no room for intelligent discourse.

Pros: * the company's name seems nice in your CV
Cons:
* no proper communication to employees
* delayed bonus + increment for months. backpay was even delayed.
* delayed promotion, not once but twice.
* you'll get stuck working with alibaba tech stack
* hr is very inefficient
* letting go of their old employees like they're sht

Pros: Can get free stuff all the time
Cons: But need to buy one first then get the free stuff.

Pros:
+Great learning curve which I can't deny.
However, in Lazada your boss determines how much you could learn. I am considered lucky to have a great leader previously where I learnt how to do planning and execution.

+In Lazada either you're a team player or lonewolf it doesn't matter much if you are in commercial team.

+You are given opportunity to meet alot of high levels guy from all companies.

+If you are the kind of person who works in fast pace this is definitely a place to go
+Great working culture, fun and young workforce.
+I am happy to see Lucy Peng taking over and focusing on people management. I love her transparency but what I wish more is that please don't only consider those who are on top, because the real executor is those from front lines. Do promote your soldiers.
Cons:
-Favoritism is a critical issue in this company
-There's no career growth/opportunity
-Lack of leadership and indecisive managers. They do not know how to provide solution to help you instead they want solution from you.
-There's no worklife balance. However, we can't complaint much, ecommerce is 24/7.
-Peanut Salary but expect output of a horse
-No proper planning, too much of adhoc
-Alot of the project PIC do not fully understand what are they doing
-Some people are so arrogant thinking that Lazada is huge in market and causes relationship that was built melt down
-Very bad transparency and communication breakdown happens often in company
-Alot of budget cutting which causes people to overwork, where a job used to take 3 person to do now it's only 1
-Your relationship with boss determines your future, your contribution or hardwork doesn't really justify that whether you're good or not.
-Company loves to force stuffs that doesn't make sense to you and expect you to force it to their clients (I think this is very unprofessional) [business shouldn't work this way if you wanted to build relationship]
-Often felt undervalued by company

Pros: Very open and fast moving company
Cons: don't have a lot of cons.

Summary: Lack of career path and leadership
Pros:
Apply for Lazada Vietnam
-If you have opportunity to work with regional team, it is awesome experience with many experts
-Nice office and some free perks like coffee, parking and dinner for overtime
Cons:
Apply to Lazada Vietnam
-Lack of coordination between business units that lead to terrible planning and experience.
-Management in my department is too junior, lack of actual expertises and lack leadership skills to inspire employees or helping customers
-The performance review is a joke, and salary review is terrible and not fair.

Pros: Huge amount of flexibility and autonomy in this role, which gives a strong feeling of trust amongst the team
Cons: Can be a lack of guidance from management

Pros: great colleagues and free foods
Cons: company does not appreciate most workers talent and is extremely rude talking to workers especially the high levels such as supervisors team leader and etc. one of the worst company and work place you wilk experience. quitting this job due to how rude they treat us and how their system is terribly lacking. everything is actually out of control. sees us as an replaceable workers as to what the other person have also reviewed about this company. even the hypocrite and faking is too much making us uneasy and uncomfortable working especially the higher levels. hoping those whom are planning to get a job here will atleast see all of the reviews or even better, you can try it in your own. first and second month you can already see how terrible they treat you.

Summary: Fell in a trap but beware
Pros: International experience and good for CV
Cons: There are lot to put here. But let me summarise it. They head hunted me from one of the top ecommerce company, bought me to a regional role. I was one man army in my team, my boss was good but lack of proper guidance and his deadlines kept changing under the pressure of top management. In the end I was one to suffer with fast implementation and deadlines. Anyways fast forward, I successfully launched the project, and time I decided to move into a different role.  Also because another team manager  wanted me in thier team to lead aproject. But withing a month, my boss quit, whole org changed. A new boss came.. Who too left and then came Aimone. All this happened in a month. Aimone is the most arrogant, bossy and unprofessional person u will find in Lazada. I wonder if there is any employee From HK who speaks good of him expect his puppets. He without even meeting or talking to anyone of our old team puts us in situation where most of us has to leave the company or fired. He didn't even bother to keep the old team or do call with us. He pre planned a org chart with his old favorites n puppets  replaced the entire old team. He destroyed many of us and our careers. When I spoke to HR about this, they knew it was not ethical but said we are helpless. So no one can save you in this company.

Pros: Extremely competitive pay for upper management
Cons:
No ownership or responsibility between team
No direction from local CEO
Lack of maturity from local CEO
Preferential treatment for Europeans

Pros:
People and Culture
Complex business problems to solve

Summary: 6 years to build and took 6 months to destroy
Pros: 6 years ago, Lazada was a high paced, aggressive, challenging, and unfriendly (at times) environment, but it gave employees opportunities to be creative, with the support at all levels. I dont know what to make of it now, just a big mess
Cons:
- Employees are leaving at an alarming rate
- Lazada VN's new CEO comes a view that everything which has been done was wrong, everyone who has been around is â€œunqualifiedâ€, as a result, new recruits from Alibaba arrived, without notice and without any introduction email
- Attempts to stabilize employees through townhalls has backfired
- At some companies we talk about perks, but here, thereâ€™s hardly anything. Over the past few months, cost cutting has been at unprecedented levels. A coffee machine for commercial and marketing team has been removed, even Yoga and English classes have been cancelled...

Summary: Was a good place to work with but culture is diluted now
Pros:
1. Very strong developers and devops culture about 2 years ago
2. Wide range of tech stack and good exposure [Chaos since strong developers left]
3. Innovation and open to new ideas [Depends on manager]
4. work life balance
5. Good compensation if you negotiate / already making switch from very good package
Cons:
1. HR policies are really bad in India and are bad joke, No proper policies/process defined
2. Lots of good developers left in SG and India
3. Recognizes employees who have loud mouth or from top companies not based on deliverables made
4. There is a huge gap in pay with in same designation in India [50 % above is common ], If you decide to join make sure you negotiate hard
5. Very frequently you will find a  guy who will write a code which has to be re-written in next year because of bad design. He would move to a different team and disown his code.
6. Existing SME / Owner will wait till something explodes and will pass on the buck to next guy or move to different project.

Summary: A sad demise to what was once a great company
Pros: Many pros before Mar 2018, when Alibaba made sweeping changes, firing the old guard who knew what they were doing and had built a legacy around the region, and motivated staff - Max was a great cheerleader and kept the fire burning in our hearts and minds.
Cons:
- Since Mar 2018, Alibaba has put Lazada into a freefall - hardly 10 people in the company (mostly Chinese people from Alibaba) and country CEOs are clued in on what changes are happening (Changes happen now every few hours, if not days)
- Zero communication below the 10 people that Ali feels matter in the company (of a size of 7000)
- Management attend useless meetings all the time with no agenda, purpose or outcome
- Peanuts salary increments and bonuses
- No line of sight into what will become of employee options/path to liquidity
- HR is doing an absolutely abyssmal job - the only job seems to be producing pages and pages of org charts which change every day, cutting roles, and focusing on firing 30% of the staff, or engineering their exit (due to staff frustration)

Pros:
- New challenges appear frequently as Lazada likes to think out of the box and circumvent roadblocks
- Never a boring day at the office
- Colleagues from different culture and job experience, great to learn from them
Cons: - Huge management change resulted in uncertain future

Summary: Start-up, acquired/managed by Alibaba, stick to slogans and low/no respect to people in top down decisions
Pros: Salary and exposure to a big pool of young talented people with passion for e-commerce
Cons: Lack of transparence in all matters (Finance, People, Tech...) . Weak leadera(s) playing political games, bringing their own trusted gang/followers and treat other employees without respect and fairness

Pros:
Lazada used to be a great company to work for: challenging but rewarding. I truly believed in company values and management was very transparent.

Pros of the existing company is that you would work with some great people hired back then. They know, what does it mean to work hard, delivering results but be cautious and not to waste money.
Cons:
Since Alibaba took over Lazada and fired CEO (Max, all the best to you), management is being replaced with Chinese nationals in all countries. Basically, Lazada turns into yet another division of Alibaba group being fully managed out of China. This means Alibaba culture, Alibaba business practices, Alibaba everything.

If you are fine with that, there will be no issue for you. If you donâ€™t like the idea of no carrier growth unless you are from Alibaba, then this place is not for you.

Also, offices in Singapore and Jakarta are badly maintained and overcrowded. I do not recommend working there, work conditions are less than ideal.

Cons:
This applies to Lazada Vietnam:
Restructuring too frequently. Especially the last restructure that had no communication from management whatsoever on what is changed, why it was changed and how to manage the change. Everything feels like top down and last minute decision. Decisions are made by a small Chinese community in a room and when they have decided on something it is published to employees outside. Company right now has no target, no direction, no roadmap. Everyone is just doing their daily job without knowing what is to come.

Cons:

Summary: Glassdoor reviews do not do it justice...it's worse
Pros: some people here are nice but they tend to be quite depressed and look worn out
Cons:
The new Alibaba HR people are not very good, it's just more and more pointless late meetings for no reasons and cost control on spending. Maybe in China HR is more old school type because company seems to be going backwards. 

It's a frustrating place to work, the crazy founders are being let go one by one but the new people just don't get our culture. When foreign companies come to Singapore they should adapt to us not us to them. Previous leaders at least tried to 'get' Singapore. 

If you want to work in an eCommerce business go to Shopee, my friend works there and although they have issues it seems better.

Pros: Lazada impressed me with its fast-paced environment and its amazing new office. I learn a lot throughout these years about e-commerce in general. You will be working with smart professional who share the passion to make the economy works. You will experience multi-cultural working experience. Many people here will welcome you warmly. They know how to work hard and party hard as well.
Cons: As a young company, I think Lazadaâ€™s management is very immature. So many changes throughout these 2 years of working. There are a lot of major changes (3 times CEO changes, a lot of shipping policy changes, 4 times major organizational structure changes and more minot changes). Moreover, all of these changes a lot of times are to be implemented immediately. As an employee, we have to execute. Many senior management does not take into account limitation in the execution and seems like all decisions are made without careful consideration and planning which in turn cost a lot. Example, the organization structure change in the middle of preparation of big campaign which makes it super hectic and not healthy. Senior management in the local market seems to be hard-headed and does not try to fit with local market culture and characteristics. Regional to local communication is also very bad. Regional tend to be bossy to local market (especially in the business side where local culture matters). The local market CEO is also very hard-headed in these terms and therefore internal communication is super chaotic. Many divisions do not know what to do and what changes are affecting them. As the result, sellers and buyers alike become the victim of these rash decision making, internal communication problem and inconsistent policy. HR is also very bad. Compare to the competitors, the benefit and facility from the company is much worse. No any intention to retain amazing talents in the company. As the result, Lazadaâ€™s organization is too small for its scale and make its employee go crazy.

Summary: Great place to learn. Terrible place to earn.
Pros: A lot of learning opportunities, a lot of exposure, and will teach you to manage stress well.
Cons:
Pays peanuts: Lazada pays at 50% of market value. 
Terrible work schedule and culture: Management has no regard for employees' personal life and preferences.
Transitioning into a hierarchical company: A lot has changed in the past 6 months, and there is a lot of hierarchy, and discrimination. The pros mentioned above are going away very quickly. 

I wouldn't consider Lazada as a long term career choice. Learn as much as you can quickly, and look for opportunities that pay better (there are plenty).

Pros: To get a shiny brand name on your CV
Cons:
First time in 10 years + career that I found myself working for such a mismanaged, inefficient and corrosive organisation. 

If you are a well-balanced, decent individual and believe in professional values such as: integrity, meritocracy, vision, transparency, then stay away from this organisation.
Lazada is basically a poorly managed Alibaba wannabe that lacks vision and strategy and the talent and structure to roll it out if they had it.

The top Management team is now made up on the one hand of the initial "boys club", and of a few Alibaba executive who were parachuted in Singapore, on the other. 

Needless to say, this unlikely cocktail is creating an ever changing, unsecure environment where priorities are constantly re-assessed.

Just trying to be objective and factual here, so here's a quick list of what's wrong with the organisation and will impact you in you daily job:

1. Lack of vision -apart from trying to tear appart competition.

2. Lack of transparency -you will only learn about a "new" strategy or project on the day it is launched or after! IF you are lucky enough to be told! 

3. Lack of communication -only type of communication I had with management (including direct line of reporting) was retro-active or micro-managing every detail from a powerpoint presentation for example. 

4. Lack of talent -Lazada primarily rewards and promotes people who are skilled in office politics and good at selling themselves and their mediocre achievements

5. Unfair -if someone at the tops decides that he/she doesn't like you, then there's virtually no barrier preventing that person from making your life a nightmare

6. No respect for people some behavior would probably considered abusive in other companies. It seems that treating people like slaves is the only way to make oneself respected here.

Pros: Great opportunities, nice to make new connect
Cons: toxic people/ no leadership, selfish, no self-improvement provide

Summary: Good for very first ladder of e-commerce career
Pros:
- Fast moving environment. Everything will push you to keep moving and adapt (or resign).
- Good for learning about e-commerce (in Thailand)
- Low barrier between employee and management team 
- Very short planning: see result from your actions fast to keep on developing
- Still have the start-up environment where your ideas are actually  implemented
- Free dinner
- Salary is rather high for new grads
Cons:
- No structure of work. Everything is messy
- No work-life balance at all (email at 8pm Friday night for deadline EOD on Saturday is regular)
- Politic. If you are happen to be a sibling of the management team, you're likely to be able to do everything , get everything , moved to anywhere and even skip work tasks that everyone has to do and get promoted
- Need strong survival skill. No mentor. Everything you have to learn by yourself and no one really knows things to teach. 
- Bonus and commission are something that always in blur line. Even the sales value which used to calculate commission can decrease by 40% on the pay day out of the blue.
- (For Key Account Manager) Difficult to reimburse phone bill like you are encouraged to just pay by yourself
- If you are Thai, very hard to be in management level. Promotion is not very transparent. 
-  It's always the Italian or French team to be in any lead whom some of them don't have knowledge about Thai market, trend, culture, and customers. And since e-commerce in Thailand is just 5 years ish, people in the company are either know only Lazada stuff (e-commerce) and nothing else about commercial or strong in the commercial (from other company) but no e-commerce experience
- Over value people that have experience in consultant firms even working there less than a year, no other experience, and have zero knowledge about market and commercial sales

Pros: Only Pros that I can think is Good salary.
Cons:
There are lots of Cons - 
1) Not at all a stable company, lots of changes were made and more are expected. People always have fear of losing their job.
2) No more good work. Under the name of DATA ENGINEERING people are just writing SQL. There is nothing to learn over here.
3) People are not at all happy with their boss. Based on politics and favouritism people are getting promoted. 
4) Core team of Data Engineering already left. Now very few good TECHNICAL people are their.
5) People are not heard, order come from the top and the team has to follow without any question asked.
6) Not at all a global company, now mandarin is mandatory.

Advise to people who are planning to join,  think before you take a decision. This LAZADA is not an old LAZADA.

Pros: This is hard for me to describe, just finding some.  The colleagues are generally friendly and supportive but this is stab someone's back as quickly as you can kinda place
Cons: This is hard for me to describe, just finding some.  The colleagues are generally friendly and supportive although there are a bunch of morons in senior levels of management who think o end of themselves and often call themselves the old Lazadaians, the tier 2 founders, etc.,  The CEO had a vision but his lieutenants failed to execute on his mission (except for the one who manages brands/ online stores) used fear mongering and lacked strategic thinking, did not like to hear another point of view and only want ass-kissers. Horizontal orgs generally surround themselves with yes-men and yes-women. If you're not "one of them" you were not in the inner circle and won't even get invited to meetings you should be a part of.  The culture is generally a lot of yelling and screaming and lack of clarity in  objecives.  Many senior CxOs like to bully (the ex CIO is an exception and well mannered). Some of the CxOs like to throw their weight around and expect you to stop your meeting and walk back to the boss's desk to answer a silly question or to have you print something that is not necessarily an urgent item. Many of them are loud mouthed power mongers and want to build armies under the guise of supporting the BUs.

Management communications are especially weak and unclear - most things are done and decided 'in secret' by senior management without communicating to lower level staff who are extremely frustrated by all the changes, no efforts are made to retain leaving employees who have contributed a lot to the company, high turnover is prevalent. Situation is so bad that people are leaving without even wanting to wait for their bonuses. Lazada culture and way of people management? Simply replacing employees as they go - they are just working machines. All of these mentioned are also so prevalent in the company regional HR department which is deemed as the core support pillar in the region. Just think how can a company actually succeed when even its own HR people are leaving the ship and good ones have already left? This is extremely disheartening and truly turn one heart's cold.

Summary: Management is full of hot air

Cons:
Management is extremely misinformed or worse. Examples are:
- In an internal "innovation" hackathon, the project that won proposed to do something that has already been implemented in the company for years. Top management who are judges and even the CEO have no idea.
- CEO takes time to go around the region to reaffirm after Alibaba acquisition that there will be no forced changes. A month later, Alibaba basically forced all tech developers to learn Java or quit.

Lazada has a decent brand name and future employers might value that
Your friends don't know what is it to work inside so you can flaunt while you die inside

Prepares you to handle anything and become immune to racism, aggression & politics
Cons:
Has the most toxic environment
C-level in Singapore encourages this and are part of the reason
Clue-less management 
Shameful to call this as a tech company

Consultants at brought to make beautiful slides to show investors and get more

Summary: "Give it a fair chance- and you will get rewards"

-Opportunity to travel (despite on budget) and learn from all the key regions in SEA

Cons:

-a more structured, and long-term solution driven manner for collaborating with local & regional, not just freak out when monthly KPIs are not reached

-Definitely need more senior women as role models and in leadership positions, some women are worried to go on maternity leave or have kids in fear of jeopardizing their career

International culture

Pros:
+ Extremely nice people
+ Challenging work
+ Good salary
Cons: - Gender ratio of workforce is not well balanced

Pros:
- Some good projects
- Good company to join if you are a fresher or with 2 years of experience.
- Good company for foreigners as they know how to get EP / S pass
Cons:
1. Poor work life balance. Stay away if you have family.

2. New recruits join with excellent job titles while old recruits who joined before Alibaba acquisition stay stagnant

3. HR play by job titles badly depending on situations and not transparent. So don't hesitate to ask for 

- Senior Vice President or Vice President titles if you have 5 to 6 years of experience.

- Senior Manager or Manager titles if you have 4 to 5 years of experience.

- Senior Associate or Associate if you have 3 to 4 years of experience 

- Senior Analyst or Analyst if you have 0 to 2 years of experience

Pros:
+ One of the best in cultural values.
+ Very young and dynamic.
Cons:
- Lack of focus in the excom level on business objectives.
- Trying too many things at the same time is detrimental to the overall progress.
- Recent silo-ed org.structure is hurting the organization's productivity.
- Too few people contribute significantly to the organization.

Summary: Fun & challenging but also negative culture
Pros: Fast moving & open environment working. Work challenging & push young people better than other big firms (at least in SEA).
Cons:
- Top managements is too immature : young & experienced everywhere and quite a "private club" where connection with lower position (especially expat manager to local employee) is poor, HR does not help any better.
- Too high turn over leading to demotivate the team in general
- Key departments are quite weak compared to other company e.g Finance, HR,...so no advise from them to make the process structured.
- Lack of middle manager positions who are actual work cause heads level is too busy chasing C- orders which also changed 80 times a day. 
- Many projects running at the same time but no aligned leading to people conflict and result trade off
- No discipline respect. Discipline is necessary for long term growth.

Summary: A startup that has grown too fast for its own good!
Pros:
-Dynamic and fast paced environment
-Super smart and awesome peers to work with
-Good facilities
Cons:
-Very clear distinction between core/imp business functions and non core ones (by SG CEO) and if you're lucky enough to be part of the "core function", you can make any number of mistakes and you'll be forgiven !  
-Very young C levels who play the blame game all the time. Impossible to learn from them on any aspect as they are themselves very clueless/don't have courage/knowledge to take decisions
-No "culture" in this company. No one knows the "values" of the company (feel free to ask around what a "lazadian" stands for ;) )
-C levels are not smart in either hiring, utilizing, or retaining talent

Summary: Great place to touch real high load
Pros:
You can learn many things there, some things that only matter at big scale. The variety of technologies is rich. Teams are autonomous at their areas of responsibilities, and very collaborative in shared areas.
Good culture of code development (strong ticket flow with required code reviews and tests).
Cons:
Working with legacy code can be tough due to high complexity. 
With newer code maintenance is often required due to changes in conventions/tech stack.

Pros: Good learning Curve in e-commerce industry
Cons: Lack of progression for local team, gap between local and expat, lack of trust to the local team

Summary: A place with meaning and impact

Rare opportunity to work on projects that have high impact and huge scale. Every thing is not already set for you, hence you need to problem solve on a daily basis to build a better service for the customers and sellers.
Very multi-cultural environment, people are young and driven, no BS mentality,  it feels you're kind of at an MBA but at work...
Cons: it's a dynamic industry, and things change fast, not every one can embrace change.

Summary: One of the best tech employers in SEA

- Great carrier opportunities
- Very strong team - a lot of strong techies
- Lots of interesting projects
Cons: - There are no cons

Pros: Freedom to pitch and implement your own ideas.
Cons: Immature and sometimes abusive management

Only way to get promoted is if you are expat!
French/Korean and Russian are the only ones to get promoted with low background without hard work. You can get promoted in 6 months or less like this!

Summary: Why do you insist on consultants?
Pros:
Great team, great working environment

A lot of people are always really helpful and it feels like a family 

Big responsibilities if you can take them on.
Cons:
High turnover, it's ridiculous. It feels almost as if the company offers exchange programs with other companies at the rate people are coming and going. 

Consultants are often placed as middle and senior management, 1% of this pool is great. They know how to work with people and are overall really good leaders. 

However the other 99% are terrible, with often high IQ's and low EQ's. These are the type of consultants who seem to have never been in contact with other human beings before and as a result their team quits or worse stays but become inefficient and demotivated. 

Icing on the cake is that Lazada C-Levels don't really care. Wait no, the real cherry on top is that if you're in management, you can find it very comfortable since you can mess up as much as you want and you won't get reprimanded.

Summary: Good company front with little personal growth
Pros:
Open Office Concept
Pantry stocked with good food
Not Hotdesking concept (You get your own desk)
Cons:
Personal Development is pretty much undefined.
Lots of SOPs not standardized, creates confusion between departments.
"Last-minute" tasks for most people.

Pros: Its people are very diverse. It's good because people get to learn from each other. The business is very fast-paced and dynamic so the teams don't do the same thing repetitively
Cons: Apart from the lack of women in Senior management, there is a huge lack on career development which causes, even the good employees, to become dissatisfied of their jobs and leave the company. Because very often, the company chooses to hire externally (and usually expats), instead of promoting hard working people who've been with the company for years.

Summary: Learn, Grow, Own Projects, Be Creative .. but take care of politics and don't be sensitive - managers might be rude.
Pros:
Great place to learn and grow

Impressive achievements that take other companies ages and overall great outlook for the future

People with various background, mixed young and experienced management

Variety of Projects

Responsibility on impactful topics

Open for new ideas and approaches

Easy to switch between fundamentally different departments (Ops, Commercial) - you can try out everything if you have the right mindset and motivation to shape your profile.
Cons:
French people prefer to hire French people, in Vietnam and even more on Regional level 

Salary differences are crazy, locally and regionally (a guy in Philippines or Indonesia will get a higher title and >50% more salary for the same job whereas the cost of living are similar to VN) 
Sometimes rude/aggressive communication in meetings 

Many intensive project kick offs which are disappearing from the radar after some time as they are not priority anymore (this is currently improving). One trigger of burning people here.

More Skype interaction than direct communication, even if you sit in front of your manager, he will rather send you a skype message than having an open discussion.

Pros: I'm in the best company of the group. The company is Lazada eLogistics. We're doing amazing things here. Colleague are friendly and helpful. Managers are open minded. We have great culture here.
Cons: I'm easy going so there is not many cons. Because we're growing so sometimes things are not right from the starting point then we need to fix it and make it better.

Summary: Customer Experience team in Singapore is a Joke

Fun and energetic environment

Pros: Fast implemenation & project speed especially in low-tech projects, open idea & discussion culture, good career accelarator for short/mid term employement (1-2 years max)
Cons: Missing clear project governance on regional and local entities, ad hoc local management decisions based on short term strategies, strong grown buddy top management culture as closed circle with rotating roles and lack of expertise / skills

Summary: Super Expat Favored "Look at the CEO and you know the team nationality"
Pros:
1. competitive and fast-moving environment
2. many smarts and committed people
Cons:
Company is losing good employees because of a culture that is too obsessed with expats that prove nothing but share the same personality with the CEO (if CEO is French then you can expect a long list of French boys just out of colleges being promoted as Head of Retail or Head of Marketing. Ops is a kingdom of Germany). 
1. Experienced employees left because they dont want to report to younger expats who literally know nothing about local markets.
2. Young employees left for competitor companies because they value more localization and the ability to communicate effectively. Many young smart employees left because they got paid far less than expats whom they went to the same university abroad.

High turnover rate... recommend for those fresh grads/early career to get some experience then go elsewhere.

Cons:

- External hiring is prevalent and hardworking employees have not career growth
- Training is just preaching, but not exercised
- Double standard working environment and ethics (HQ vs warehouse)

- Technologically restricted (your tech team has no idea what operations need, and tech development is completely on the opposite of the spectrum)
- Fragmented systems, sync issues, bad communication between regional and local, and local ventures are left to pickup bread crumbs to make things work
- Many more

Cons:

2.) No consideration for sick employees. Will ask you to come work even if you have a burning fever.
3.) Supervisors and team leaders are very rude. 
4.) Team meetings will take 2-3 hours of your time without pay.

Cons: There is a culture issue, with much of management inexperienced in managing and subsequently poor at time and resource allocation. This results in significant amounts of unnecessary work and poor planning. This ultimately leads to unsurprising high employee turnover.

There is usually no clear direction from management and KPIs change a lot. Work-life balance is not exactly encouraged and you're expected to work long hours.

Pros:
- You can get promoted if you're good enough without considering of how young you are. Your bosses also very young. Around 20 somethings.

- Staff are good, young, dynamic and open-minded. If you're fresh graduated or already have 2,3 years of working, you can easily get along well with your team. 

- Many open projects and positions for you to try. Unless you're afraid of trying. 

- SEA region > you can expand your working experiences to the other countries as well.

- Pay well for some positions.
Cons:
- Many French people.
- If you've been studied abroad or you're not Vietnamese, more chance you got consideration to be promoted as Head. 
- the whole company is growing super fast, so the organization setup couldn't catch up with the business well. Its quite complicated and change a lot.
- KPI will haunt you to your dream. Be prepared!
- Pressure is coming from upon your head, behind your back, opposite to your desk and even just next to you. Because It's a open working space. Your boss is sitting at the same table you're and sometimes you would get a tap on the back from your CEO.

Pros:
1. Good compensation and benefits. 
2. Good work location
3. Easy promotion
Cons:
1. Regularization is after a year.
2. Shifting schedule (for customer service - even for local account)

Summary: Great place to gain experience but poor benefits
Pros:
1. Great place to gain experience especially if you just graduated from school. Depending on which team you are on, you get to learn from qualified managers who have acquired much experience under their belt.  Would recommend only if you do not mind the poor remuneration that comes with the heavy workload

2. A good platform to exhibit your hidden talents especially if you are a high achiever. However, You have to be a loud person as well.
Cons:
1. Poor working culture. It is expected of you to work long hours without the due compensation. Clocking in more work hours without necessarily being more efficient = perceived to be more hardworking

2. They have a strong preference for hiring expats at the C level, mostly hired without any ecommerce experience. Might be due to the fact they can clock in working hours without any leadership skills to lead the team to the next level. You are expected to tread in the water yourself and at the best time be an adviser to the same group of people while getting low or below market average pay.

3. No retention strategies. Not surprising since the turnover rate for HR is also relatively high.

4. Poor benefits, monetary and non monetary included

Summary: Cannot be a long term job
Pros: many change and challenge job nature so that you can learn more.
Cons: Stress, don't have opportunity to growth or promotion, foreigners are welcome but local HK people will not be a asset for them.

Summary: Best Career Move for the most ambitious
Pros:
- Steep Learning Curve.
- Working together with Top Management.
- Ability to move around in the company doing whatever is interesting for you.
- Super Smart collegues coming from top companies and excellent academic background.
- Probably best place to learn about e-commerce and Internet.
- Possibility to make a direct impact on the company performance.
Cons: - Lots of responsibility means also meeting tight deadlines and working under pressure.

Pros:
It is start up so you get the chance to form the company and that goes for all titles. 

Part of a team that is building a new industry and who are pushing to stay number 1. 

If you show initiative and persists the sky is the limit I got promoted 4 times in 2.5 years.

There a few places where you will learn as much in such a short time.

It is getting more corporate where it counts like quality of hotels have greatly improved.
Cons: The growth is very fast from zero to USD 1.3 billion in sales in 4 years. So processes lack behind and the tone can be a bit ruff. But you will learn from many talented ex consultants and ecommerce experts from from the likes of BCG and Amazon.

Pros: Fantastic opportunities, room for personal growth, lots of freedom on your daily job, high calibre management, "can do" attitude

2. Severely underpaid for the level/quality of work management expects, stress, and hours put in (unless you are part of the senior management)

3. Management seems to be "fire-fighting" most of the time - they are not sure what is the best for the company,

Pros: Great people and environment - having to work wi different people in this company had me exposed to different level of greatness.. In which im truly proud
Cons: Everyone is your boss - too many managers and no clear hirarchy. Who you are reporting to.. Which is hard to balance.

Summary: Changes structure and direction faster than my seasonal wardrobe change
Pros: Could potentially be a great environment for innovation and creativity if you get on the right side with the right senior management. Great diversity of people, C class officers openly promoting their illicit recreational activities - if this was a club not a workspace.
Cons:
Senior management changes their minds at the speed of lightening, a bunch of number crunches with no long-term focus. Expats and fresh grads in management positions yet displaying no leadership skills and HR is white worshipper, does not give a cent about employee wellbeing nor benefits unless you are an expat.

Our team spent 6 months on a project which got shut down because business 'changed directions'. A month later CEO sends an appreciation email to the entire company commending the project and encouraging similar initiatives - looks like Max don't have much clue as to what happens in his company. For every 5 new employees I see that gets hired, 3 leaves. Says a lot about the company.

Pros:
The team spirit usually has to be quite strong as there are a lot of adversities to overcome together.  

It's ecommerce?
Cons:
- senior mgmt hired from consulting backgrounds are all clueless about local market. Taking wild potshots. Speculations.  Failed bets.  

- empty promises to clients that really screwed them over

- employees treated like trash.  Gave a member of the team a PIP,  he was hitting his KPIs but fired anyway (unethical) 

- directional changes all the time from MD levels who are hopeless.  Bonds the team together but really gives a sense of dread

- insane title inflation.  A lot of fake MDs with zero reports just meant to fluff the company up for investors.

Pros: Easy to get in. Good name in Indonesia.

Organization structure is changing every day. Got the messiness of a startup, but also the bureaucracy of a big company.
Company  invest in marketing but not improving the product itself. Product team is terrible. The back-end system is so backward but the company has no intention to improve.
I don't know why the company is so proud of having 4000+ workers with this size. Maybe labour is too cheap in this region that they don't mind creating more and more manual processes, instead of hiring a few smart guys to create smarter process. 
Management doesn't care about your growth. People are leaving every single day. There is no sense of belongingness at all. If somebody do an unofficial poll, I wouldn't be surprised if more than 50% is thinking about quitting this company.
No equity and low salary.

Summary: Lazada sucks - Suspect other reviews which are overwhelmingly positive as fake reviews
Pros: Not much besides the casual dress code
Cons:
Managers no empathy and understanding
Benefits minimal to non existent, HR lies to your face and uses outdated and useless policies.
Attrition rate is 50% or higher.
Facilities are basic and it's lucky if you have a space at a desk even.
No leadership and you are left to drown yourself.
No performance updates or KPI's given at times.
C Level all young and all don't care about the staff well being at all. Seen people getting fired or forced to resign often.
Suggestions and ideas never followed up on. No sign of clear direction besides profit and growth.
Focus entirely on keeping growth high to attract investors/buyer - sustainability never looked at

Pros:
Opportunity to grow quickly in scope and responsibilities
Given responsibilities for teams, projects, P&L etc. quickly
Startup spirit and young colleagues
Outstanding work gets recognised
Cons:
Extremely cheap (overcrowded office, no meeting rooms, no benefits, etc.)
Low salary, well below market
Very disorganised (no structure, no published org chart, leave applications still on paper, no or bad planning of projects)
Poor and inexperienced management, mainly testosterone-based and old school (very young, knee-jerk decisions, not always conducting annual reviews, time-watching, no work from home, etc.)
Poor company culture, no values, no humanity
Glass ceiling above certain level and great inequalities in treatment between senior management and mid/low-level staff
Poor work life balance
